You are given a qubit that is either in state $|0\rangle$ or state $|+\rangle$. Your task is to determine which state the qubit was in. You can perform operations on the qubit and make measurements, but you cannot perfectly distinguish between the two states.

Here are the rules:

* You must never incorrectly identify the state. This means:
    * Never return 0 if the input state was $|+\rangle$.
    * Never return 1 if the input state was $|0\rangle$.
* You can return -1 (inconclusive) at most 80% of the time.
* You must correctly identify $|0\rangle$ at least 10% of the time.
* You must correctly identify $|+\rangle$ at least 10% of the time.

The input will consist of 50% $|0\rangle$ states and 50% $|+\rangle$ states.

You need to write a function that takes a qubit as input and returns an integer (0, 1, or -1).

You are given a system that can be in one of two states. You need to figure out which state it is in by performing operations on it. You can't be 100% sure which state it is, but you need to be very accurate and make sure you don't get the states mixed up.  You also need to be able to say when you can't be sure.
